greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of partitions of n having exactly k parts that appear exactly once (n>=0, k>=0).
comment: Row n has 1+floor([sqrt(1+8n)-1]/2) terms. Row sums yield the partition numbers (A000041). T(n,0)=A007690(n). Sum(k*T(n,k),k>=0)=A024786(n+1).
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..500, flattened
formula: More generally, g.f. for the number of partitions of n having exactly k parts that appear exactly m times is product((t-1)*x^(m*j)+1/(1-x^j), j=1..infinity). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Feb 21 2006
maple: g:=product(1+t*x^j+x^(2*j)/(1-x^j),j=1..40): gser:=simplify(series(g,x=0,23)): P[0]:=1: for n from 1 to 21 do P[n]:=sort(coeff(gser,x^n)) od: for n from 0 to 21 do seq(coeff(P[n],t,j),j=0..floor((sqrt(1+8*n)-1)/2)) od; # yields sequence in triangular form
b:= proc(n, i) option remember; local j; if n=0 then 1
elif i<1 then 0 else []; for j from 0 to n/i do zip((x, y)
mathematica: b[n_, i_] := b[n, i] = Module[{j, pc}, If[n == 0, pc = {1}, If[i<1, pc = {0}, pc = {}; For[j = 0, j <= n/i, j++, pc = Plus @@ PadRight[{pc, If[j == 1, {0}, {}] ~Join~ b[n-i*j, i-1]}]]; pc]]]; T[n_] := b[n, n]; Table[T[n], {n, 0, 30}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 31 2014, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 18 2006
